South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 1 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
RED SEA LINE.

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER."

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature's Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.
Depot for Egypt : J. McGregor, Chemist.

div.head: A SUICIDAL POLICY
div.p: Ministers are losing no time in giving practical effect to the policy which, according to Mr. Haldane, will have the double advantage of inviting other Powers to a reduction oi armaments while increasing the fighting value of our own by fifty per cent. Oa Saturday week, then, in pursuance of that policy, the third Battalion of the Scots Guards surrendered its colours to the King, and ceased to exist in its corporate capacity. The parade was, naturally enough, made as private an affair as possible; it was not a ceremony which anyone present, from His Majesty down to the smallest band-boy, could regard as a combination of duty with pleasure. Never the ass, for our part, says the "PallMa'l Gazette,' we should not have been sorry if the King had invested the ceremony with every attribute of publicity, and had held the parade in Hyde Park before the eye3 of assembled London. It would, in our judgment, have been a very good thing to have brought home visibly—"because things seen are mightier than things heard"—to the people the fact that our present pastors and masters are dshborately wipeg out of existence a whole battalion of the finest troops in the world, and that this is but the first stop in a process of wholesale disarmament such aa has never been witnessed before in the history of -he British Army. Had the public been present we doubt not that many hearts would have echoed the words reported to have been used by an ofli cer who saw the Battalion pass on its march to Buckingham Palaca. "Please God we never want in a hurry what we are throwing away in a hurry. " Of the opinion entertained by the King as to the wisdom of the polioy of relnotion, some idea' maybe formed from the striotly constitutional terms in which his Majesty referred to that policy: "My Government has considered it neoessary to reduce the expense! of the Army." There was, moreover, a note of resur rection in his Majesty's declaration that he would receive tin colours rather as a deposit than as a gift: 'I shall always preserve them religiously and carefully at Buckingham Palace, aa I hope that it may be possible for me, or at any rate my successor, to see a third Battalion of the Scots G jards carrying tin ^ame colours again." Unless, then, we are to assume that Edward the Peacemaker has been suddenly smitten with the madness of "militarism," we must conclada that he, at all events, does not believe that the Golden Age isaboat to return, and that England and her Sovereign can safely dispense with the services of any appreciable portion of the British Armyx However, the King reigns, and good Sir Henry governs. "The British infantry are the finest in the world ; fortunately there are very few of them," said Marsh*! Bugeand. They will now be fewer still; but whether fortanately or unfortunately depends, of coarse, on the point of view.

It is a wholesome exercise for a natioD, as for an individual, to try to Bee itself aa others see it, especially when the nation in question lives on an island, and is therefore rather prone to the habit of mental isolation. Let os sae then, what our neighbours thiuk of our policy of Daval and military reduction, or, at least, of the naval part of the business for they have already expressed themselves with regard to the other. Three points emerge from the comments of the French and German Press, and of Count Reventlow„ the German naval expert, who has expressed his opinion in an interview. In the first place, British Daval reduotion will amount to very little. Secondly, British naval supremacy is so well assured for the immediate future that England can well afford to p03e as the Angel of Peace. Thirdly, that, whatever England may consider herself justified in doing in this direition, neither France nor Germany has the faintest intention of following snit. That, then, is the brutal, naked truth ; nobody is going to follow our lead, because, to begin with, onr reductions ate considered quite inadequate to affect the existing balance of naval power, and because, if they were not, nobody would be so foolish not to take advantage cf British ineptitude for his own benefit. It comes, therefore, to thip, that England is to appear before the Conference at The Hague to ask the other Powers as to follow her example by reduoing their armaments, albeit (by her own admission) she has not made any reductions snffi.ient to endanger her own naval supremacy—a fact of which her neighbours are perfeotly well aware. We find ourselves, then, between the horns of a dilemma ; either our redaction of armaments is a sham, or it is fraught with danger to oar supremacy on sea and to the adequate defence of the Empire on land. We cannot have it both w*ys; but unfortunately, that is jast what thaGovernmentare trying todo, and the attempt has this peril in it, that in striving to offer the Conference at The Hague convincing proof of their burning zeal for peace, they will serionsly impair the national strength both afloat and ashore, thereby merely tempting our rivals to redouble their efforts to overtake us. The value of the British Navy as a fictor in the preservation of peace doas not consist ia mere ability to fight, but in being so unquestionably powerful that no Power, or combination of Powers, shall dare try conclusions with it. The nation, careless and apathetic though it is, really knows that well enough, and, if the Government do not, we have good hope that the Conference at The Hague will convince them that other Powers do not mean to leave off shipbuilding to please the one Great Power in Earope which "seeks no territories" and only desires to koep what it has got. The voios of England is merely that of one crying in tha wilderness.

div.head: ABYSSINIAN JUSTICE.
div.p: MENEL1K INTERFERES IN FAVOUR OF A GERMAN.

The Berlin "LokalaDzeiger" recently publish ed a communication on German infience in Abyssinia which has been widely quoted in the German Press, generally accompanied by com ments to the effeot that the .Emperor Menelik has more respect for Germany than lor any other Power. The communication states that he commercial treaty which was concluded between Germany and Abyssinia, as a result of Geheimrat Rosen's mission to the Abyssinian Court last year, is a great improvement on the commercial treaty concluded between other European Powers and Abyssinia, inasmuch as it exempts German sabjects in Abyssinia from the jarisdiotion of native Abyssinian courts •»nd places them under German consular juris- liction. The subjects of all other Powers in Abyssinia are placed under the jurisdiction of the Abyssinian courts, and are thus subjected to a most inadequate and unfair administration ofjastioe. The communication conclude! with describing a case which occarred iu the interior of Abyssinia, where a German trader was greatly •annoyed and harassed in his business operations by the local Abyssinian chieftain. The Genian Charge dAffaires at Adis Abeba lodged an energetic protest, and Menelik immediately ordered that the tff-jnding chiePain -hoald be deposed. This drastic punishment, says the communication, is unique in the records of Abyssinian relations with foreign Powers, and excited great astonishment among the Englith and French rebdents at 'Adis Abeba.

div.head: Fire in a Stable.
div.p: This morning at 3 o'clock fire broke oot in a wooden stable neu Gabbari. Three horses were burned to death and two other horses received serious injuries, while some carriages were destroyed. The damage is estimated at L.E. 30?. The fire was reported to have been caused by a lamp which foil from the ceiling of the Btable on some straw.

div.head:
PUBLIC MORALITY
TEXT OF NEW LAW
div.p: The following are the regulations, which Europeans residing in Egypt will have to conform to, as decreed at the recent meeting of the Counoil of Ministers A fine not exceeding L.E. 1 and imprisonment for not longer than oue wok will be iutlioted on the following :— (1) Persons who in towns or villages bathe in an indecorous manner or are thas discovered in the highways. (2) Persons who are discovered on the highways and public places in a state tf manifest drunkenness. (3) Persona who cn the highways, in pnblio places, or before their biases, excite the passers-by to be dissolute by gests or words. When such persons are below twelve years of age their parents will be held responsible. (4) Persons who have induced children to solicit alms on the highways or in public places.

div.head: THE 3rd COLDSTREAM GUARDS.
div.p: Some hope is still entertained of saving the 3rd Coldstream Guards. Their chance of preservation lies in the fact that they have been selected for service abroad, embarking for Egypt on September 29 A sigt ificant fact in connection with their hopes of ootliviDg the proposal to reduce the regiment lies in the decision just come to with regard to a sergesDt- majorship that becomes vacant this week, when Sergeant-Major Shipley, ot the 1st Battalion, leaves to take up au appointment at the Royal Hibernian School.

Representations were made to the regimental orderly-room that it would be unwise to promote a non-commissioned officer in his place in view of the fact that there wouli be within the next few months a warrant officer to be absorbed from the 3rd Battalion. The matter was taktn to higher quarters, and the decision since couimuuicated is that the senior drill- eergeant of the 2nd Battalion is to be promoted sergeant major of the 1st Battalion, and his appointment is to be fi'led without delay. This, taken in conjunction with the faot that officers are advising their non commissioned officers to "soldier or," is significant; the married people of the 3rd Battalion are being told that they ceed not fear that their stay in Egypt will be as brief as present circumstances indicate. All these things certainly give an impression that there are powerful agencies at work to save at least one of the two threatened battalions.

div.head: A.M K Kir AN CORN FOR EGYPT-
div.p: FIRST SHIFMENT TO THIS COUNTRY IN ABOUT EIGHT YEAR3.

Baltimore, July 7. A character of unusual interest has been noted on 'Change. The British steamer Mookta haR Iren engaged to carry a full cargo of corn this month to Alexandria. It is understood that Messrs. Hammond and Snydor are the shippers

It has been seven or eight years since Baltimore has shipped corn to Egypt. Some time ago many shipments were made. It is not believed that the present shipment means in any sense a revival of this trade, but that it is rather a freak.

It is also rather unusual for a full cargo of corn to be shipped from this port in July. DariDg the past winter it was known that there were many charters for July and August, but these were for the most part canceled. It is rumoured, however, that there will be several large shipments during August.

div.head:
THE DENISHWAI AFFAIR.
THE CHARGES OF BRIBERY
div.p: The discussion aroused by the charges of bribery brought by Mr. Mansfield de C. Findlay against the European and native Press still continues in the vernacular newspapers. Meanwhile the European newspapers, whose attitude during the Denishwai campaign led to their being included in Mr. Findlay's accusation, also intend moving in the matter. The "Journal du Caire'' yesterday remarked:

Toute la presse s'apprête à répondre à l'accusation grave dont elle vient d'être l'objet. Mais il faut y mettre quelque perspicacité et à propos. C'est une injure qui comporte une justification publique.

"Al Zaher" makes the following comments : —Not long ago Lord Cromer abused the Moslem papers, ascribing untruthfulness to their statements, because they published what they considered to be the trnth in regard to the Akaba affair ; and now Mr. Findlay, the British Chargé d'Affaires, brings charges of bribery against the local Press —both European and native—for their publications regarding the Denishwai affair. Both Mr. Findlay and Lord Cromer have coloured their assertions with serious exaggeration. Mr. Findlay's charges are, we believe, baseless. They are merely a result of some political views. He who allows himself to charge the Egyptian Press with corruption for criticising the Denishwai sentence may just as well bring the same charges against those Members of Parliament who severely criticised this identical sentence, declaring that it was based on neither justice nor law. If any bribes at all were given to newspapers as a subsidy, those papers must undoubtedly be two: one European and the other Arabic.

"Al Ahram" says Mr. Findlay is very much mistaken in levelling charges of bribery against the European and native Press of Egypt in general. "We never expected to hear such charges from such a capable man as Mr. Findlay is. "We cannot, therefore, help criticizing the extraordinary policy of this gentleman, but at the same time we must acknowledge the violent tone of some of our papers. What proof could Mr. Findlay bring to show that his curious charges are true ? Who are the natives who have so generously spent the large sum of money which should be enough to subsidize the whole of the papers of Egypt ? It is unjust to despise the papers which render the best services to the country and whose assistance had been appreciated by Lord Cromer himself. If Mr. Findlay will deign to listen to the opinion of a paper which has served the Egyptian nation for 30 years, "Al-Ahram'' will take the liberty to point out that the British Occupation has exaggerated the charges of religious fanaticism and brought the last charges of bribery against the whole of the Egyptian Press only to pave the way for some future line of policy and to suppress the liberty of the Press. But the slightest diminution of that liberty will be considered as a crime committed against the nation, which hears no voice except that of its Press."

div.head:
ARMENIANS IN EGYPT.
PATRIARCH'S COMMUNICATION.
HOPES OF PEACE.
div.p: The Armerian Orthodox colony at Alexandria is still agitated on the subject of its constitution. The recent crisis, which led to the resignation of Bartau Pasha and his nominees, is by no means at an end, and the elebtions have led to no result, for the members of the new council resigned one after another, for reasons which are not exactly known, and no council now exists.
We hear that the Egyptian Government has informed the leaders of the party which deposed Bartau Pasha, that until the return of Boghos Pasha Nubar from Europe matters had better remain in statu quo.
The Orthodox Armenian Patriarchate at Constantinople has sent an official communication to the old council, of which Bartan Pasha was president. The text of this document is as follows :--

By your letter, dated 30th June, you inform us that according to our latest instructions you continue temporarily to hold your office, but that you do not take part, within the jurisdic tion of the archbishopric, in the meetings the aim of which is to form a provincial administra- tion. As you are aware, according to instruc- tion issued by this Patriarchate, the Bishop of your See, Mgr. Megherditch, was entrusted with the election of a local board for Alexandria, by sending us in advance a report concerning the electoral preparations. We are, however, astonished to hear that instead of having a local board elected, the Bishop has proceeded to form a separate General Provincial Assem- bly for Alexandria, as if that town were a detached and independent See from that of Egypt in general. The Bishop brings forward, in order to exculpate himself, varions excuses and also certain influence which have been brought to bear upon him. In the Mixed Council of the Central National Administration this action of the Bishop's was discussed, and the Mixed Council did not consider that this proceeding was in any way legal:
1. Because the Bishop had no order but to form a Local Board, and it was beyond his powers to undertake other duties.
2. Because the grant to Alexandria of a pro- vincial general assembly and an administrative body of her own wou'd mean a division into two parts of the See of Egypt.

It is natural that the National Central Admi- nistration could not accept such a separatist body, which is contrary to our traditional rules and to our national constitution. The adminis- tration, moreover, could not understand how the Bishop, who ho'ds his authority from this Patriarchate, and is recognized as such before the local authorities by an Imperial Firmar, could infringe the instructions of our Patriar- chate, the canons of our Holy Church, and the laws of our nation, by acting in such a way. The Bishop must well bear in mind that Alexandria forms only a part of the Egyptian See, although certainly an important part. She is entitled to have her own representatives in the General Provincial Assembly in Cairo, which city is Egypt's diplomatic centre and the seat of the See, and to elect by scrutiny her own local board, which in its turn is responsible to the Civil Council, constitated by the general provincial assembly in Cairo.

The National Central Administration could, if needs be, allow the Alexandrian community, in view of their increased number, to have a number of representatives equal to that of Cairo, thus possessing a voice and a vote, according to their position, in the administra- tion of the general affairs of the See. Such is the legal manner of the administrative bodies in all Sees, and all special instructions are based on these principles. The arrangements made by the Bishop are evasions of the law and render him responsible, a responsibility which is the more serious as it is tantamoun to separating the only See in Egypt. Th duties of the Bishop are, therefore, to make his arrangements by taking as a base the identical legal principle as explained heretoe fore. He should in the second place enter into negociation with the General Provincial- Assembly in Cairo, and come to a complete understanding with these two great parties of the Egyptian See in Cairo and Alexandria. He ought not to assume a needless responsi- bility by giving an appearance of legality to his arbitrary proceedings.

We, therefore, have transmitted to the Bishop of Egypt these remarks of the National Central Administration, and have recom- mended him to act in a legal manner, and to submit to the Central Administration such sound proposals as will be always attended to, provided that they do not infringe the tradi- tional law and the principles of our National Constitution as concerns the organisation of Sees.

Whereas the Provincial General Assembly in Cairo have a voice in this question of administrative organization, and whereas every arrangement should be made after a good understanding has been arrived at, we have counselled the Bishop to await the return of the president of the Provincial General Assembly, H.E. Boghos Pasha Nubar, and not to embark in hasty measures, the consequences of which might be prejudicial. We at the same time draw the attention of our Alex- andria compatriots, who have shown them- selves so attached to the law, in order that they shall know to hearken to the remarks of the Central Administration with the same loyal spirit. It is sufficient if the Bishop explains formally and intelligibly these dispositions of the law, without any hesitation or weakness, whatsoever exigencies may arise. Furthermore, and lastly, we urge the honourable Council to give ear to the observations of the Central Administration and to use their best endea- vours so that the affairs of the diocese may be placed on a legal foundation and that peace and harmony may thereby be attained. (Signed) MALACHIA.

It is hoped that this communication of the Patriarch of Constantinople, whose hierarchical jurisdiction embraces the ancient See of Egypt, will be received by the Orthodox Armenian community of Alexandria with all the defe- rence due to the exalted ecclesiastical rank of the reverend author, and that the unfortunate friction that has recently taken place will now be at an end, so that when Boghos Pasha Nubar returns from Europe he will find it an easy task to conciliate all the contending factions.

div.head: FANATICISM IN EGYPT.
div.p: MU ST A I'll A KASHA KAMEI.'S OPINION.
Mustapha Pasha Kamel sends the following letter to the "Tribune":
Now that Egypt and the Egyptians are so much discussed in England, permit me to say a word npon a question which we, more than all others, naturally have at heart.

Sir Edward Grey having spoken in the House of Commons of the alleged fanaticism of the Egyptians, the English people ask how it is possible th it each fanaticism can exist after twenty four years of British occupation. And they are right in their surprise, inasmuch as "fanaticism" means, in European ears, love of barbarism and hatred of Christians. If snch a feeling existed in Egypt, it would imply the downfall of the English Administration and o* European civilization on Egyptian soil.

Bat, by the leave of Lord Cromer and Sir Edward Grey, that fanaticism has DO existence. There is, indeed, a national movement, bat not a fanatical movement. There is a national movement that shoald be approved by all j net and hnmane men, for its aim is to set Egypt QDder a liberal rale that would permit free iife on the banks of the Nile, and would allow effort, talent, and industry their due success. We have, in fact, long made our device of the words, "Liberty for ourselves, a welcome for the stranger."

If some Englishmen have forgotten the engagements entered into by the British Government—the promise of "Egypt for the Egyptians"—the Egyptians have not forgotten it. Independence wap, and ip, the supreme aspiration of our lives. It is Baid—and said assuredly in bad faith - that we do but wish to change oar masters, and that we are led captive by Tarkish intrigue, or by German, as the case may be. The same thing was said when France urged the evacnation of Egypt. Bnt it is a oalamDy, and it will not hold.

Those who speak thus of us should remember that Egypt definitively accepted Western civilization more than a century ago, that she is not like Morocco, nor like any other nation of Africa or of Asia, and that she possesses an edaoated class fully as intellectual as are the edaoated clasee* of Earope. And how can Egyptians of education do otherwise than desire the liberty of their conntry ? And how shoald saoh a wish seem strange to-day, which was allowed to be natural and lawful a short quarter of a century ago?

Lord Cromer has prodaced no proof of the fanatioism of Egypt—that "lanaticism" which has so often and so long been need as a weapon against ns. The only proof offered by Lord Cromer to England is the anonymous letter ot a Mussulman. Is it not rather a disproof that is to be found in this letter ? And wonld England have been able to place Englishmen at the head ot the Egyptian State and at the head of the Egyptian Army if the Egyptian people had been fanatics ? Would England have been able to lead Egyptian foroes to the Sadan against the Sadane3e Mussulmans if there had been a Mussulman fanatioism in Egypt ? Wonld she hava succeeded in condemning twenty-one Mussulmans to terrible punishments—hangings, Hoggings, and hard labour—for the accidental death of one English officer and injary to two others l Was not the Denishwai inoident snffioient to provoke an outbreak of fanaticism if fanatioism existed ? No, a thoosand times, it does not exist. What does exist is national feeling; what does exist is bitterness that justice should so fail.>

It has been said in England, and repeated, that the Sinai inoident proved the existence of fanatioism. And yeh, daring the whole incident, there were no meetings, no demonstrations, no disturbances. A controversy in the Press there was, indeed; but this was all. Is this fanaticism! And what impartial Englishman will blame the interest taken by the Mussulmans of Egypt in a question touching the railway of Hedjaz and the pilgrimages?

Some amoug the honest Europeans who confess oar freedom from fanatioism have protested in Egyptian newspapers against the speeoh of Sir Edward Grey. I believe, with my countrymen, that Sir Edward Grey spoke in Parliament of Egyptian fanaticism for no other purpose than to stifle discussion on the horrible facts of Denishwai. Bnt is it worthy of England, the coantry that professes humanity, jastice, and oivilisation, to approve and adopt the acts of those who gave the world that melancholy and dreadful spectacle of barbarism—the exeoations of Denishwai?

The direction of the Ronmanian Maritime Service has just been informed that the speed trals of the S.S. Imperatnl Trajan, which have been carried ont at St. Nbzaire, are very satisfactory. Judging by these trials, it is expected that the vessel will be able to do the voyage between Constat za and Alexandria in an average of 64 hoars.

Aziz Pasha Izzet, Under-8eoretary of State for Foreign Affairs in Egypt, accompanied by Izzet Bey, Arabic secretary to H. H. tin Khedive, and MichalakiBey Tambowa, of the Khedivial Mail Line, paid a visit the day before yesterday to the Patriarchate of Phanar. In the absence of the Patriarch the visitors were received by the Archimandrite Calli nicos.
Tbe Italian Embassy announces that Sig. Natale Labia, t^feve-consnl here, ha9 been transferred in the same quality to Alexandria.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Mr. Machell sailed yesterday from Port Said for Earope, and duriug his absence Lord Edward Cecil Pauli* will be acting Adviser to the Ministry of the Interior.

At its last sitting the Conned of Ministers decided to grant a bonas of L. E. l,5r0 to Mr. Clowe?, Inspeotor-Ganeral of Irrigation in Upper Egypt, for services rendered daring the last eight years. Mr. Clowes has a contract with the Government for fifteen years, with the stipulation that at the close of that period he shoald reoeive a bonas of L. E. 3,000. As, however, he has had to resign for reasons of health half of this snm has been paid him.

It is stated that Miralai Owen Bey, who has been struck off the strength of the Egyptian Army, will shortly be appointed Undersecretary of State for War, in place of Ismail Pasha Sarhank, who is to retire.
The "Mokattam" announces that in view of the present situation, Mansfield Pasha, Commandant of the Cairo Police, will not go on leave this year.
Dr. Abbate Pasha, Chairman of the Khedivial Geographical Society, has returned from his two months' holiday tour in Gresoe and Italy, coming last from Palermo, his native place.
Dr. Graham, of the Sanitary Administration, has returned to Cairo from his inspection of Alexandria.
Miralai Mohamed Bey Tewfik, director of the Military School, has obtained three months' leave on private affairs.
Dr. Gotsohlioh, sanitary inspector of Alexandria, and Dr. Valassoponlos, head snrgeon of the Hellenio Hospital, will represent Egypt at the Sanitary Congress to be held in Geneva.
Sheikh Abd-El-Kerim Moured, the apostle of Pan Islamism, is now in Cairo. H 3 leave) shortly for Morocco.
We regret to record the death of Mr. Charles Le Bihan, ex-chef de onisine of Lord Cromer,

div.head: DEATH OF MOHAMED PASHA CHERIF.
div.p: The death is reported from Paris of H. E. Mohamed Pasha Cberif, ex-Secretory of State for Foreign Affairs, after a long and painfnl illness. Deceased was one of the sons of the late Cherif Pasha, the eminent statesman who, nnder tye-teign of Ismail and that of Tewfik played a prominent role in the coantry. He was about fifty years of age.

div.head: THE LATE COL. MONCRIEFF.
div.p: Colonel Sir Alexander Moncrieff, K.C.B., F.R 8., whose death is announced by Renter to day, was born in 1829. DariDg the Crimean War Sir Alexander Monorieff, then a lieutenant in the Forfarshire Militia, went to the seat of war, and received the permission of the Commander-m-Chief to visit the siege works, and to be present at the operations as a Militia officer, daring the first and second bombardments of Sevastopol. It was then .that the idea of the invention with which his Dame is aseociated occurred to his mind ; bnt it was some years before it was matured into a praotioai form. It was first submitted by Captain Monorieff to General Sir Richard Daores, Commanding tbe Royal Artillery in Iceland, at Dablin in 1857, and it was some years more before the authorities were induced to give it a trial, after which Captain Monorieff was engaged for eight years in the Royal Arsenal attached to the Department of the Direotor of Artillery. The Moncrieff System of Mounting Artillery, or the protected barbette system, is sometimes called the Disippearing System, because upon firing, the g^nn reooils into shelter, oat of sight of the tyiemy, and the energy of tfie recoil is stored up so as to raise the gnn into the firing position when loaded. la the first instance this was effected by means of a connterweight; and the interposition of a moving fulcrum (then for the first time employed in praotioai mechanics) enabled the Bodden impetus of the discharge to be utilised without danger to the carriage. Another method by which the same end is accomplished, and which is applicable to sea service, and to many oases in which the direct foroe of gravity wonld be unwieldy or nnsnitable for application, is MonoriefFs Hydro pneumatic System. In this case the recoil of the gan drives down a piston, which foroes water into a vessel of compressed air,and the farther compression of the air stores up the energy of the recoil to raise the gn n to the firing position when required. His system is now largely and increasingly nsed i n tfce British Service, both by land and sea; and it is nsed also by foreign Governments.

div.head: QUESTIONS MUNICIPALS.
div.p: Monsieur leDireotear de 1'"Egyptian Gazette." Suivant la dernier compte reuda de la Com mission Manioipale, le Ministere des Finaoces a consign^ a la Manioipalit^ la partie de9 fortifications, aitude au nord de U Porte Rosette ; quant k la partie sod il a decide d'attendre pour la consigner le r£soltat des travaux d'em- bellissement executes dans la partie nord. Lk- desans, la D^l^gation a imm^diatement eetit k S.E. le Ministre de l'lnt^rieur "exposant lea travaux faits et lea rdanltats obtenos et signa- lant lea inconv^nients qui rdsulteraieut de l'interroption des travaux d'embelliasement dont tout le public d' Alexandrie attend aver impatience 1' achievement."

La Commission a approovd les termea de la lettre adressde par la Legation et a decide d'maiater auprks de S.E. le Ministre pour que la consignation des terrains necessaires du pare sod ait lien le pins tot possible.

Qoe les membres de la D^dgation et de la Commission, qui sont des propri^taires poor la plopart, a'interesaent k la consignation des fortifications poor en faire des pares, cela se con^oit; mais qu'ils pr^tendent obtenir oette consignation au nom de toot le public Alexandrin, cela est bfirement exceasif. Le publ'c en question se ddsintdresse compliment de l'affaire des pares; ceox-ci, par leur situation mGme au milieu d'un quartier aristocratiqoe, sont a pen press exclosivement destines a l'usage des bonnes et des enfants des riches qui en out moins besoin que tous les autres, ayaot a leur disposition de beaux jardins ombrag^s et de magnifiques villas. Ce que desire la population de notre ville, ce qui est n^cessaire pour la sant^ gdn^rale, o'est le percament de graades artkrea dans les quartiers malsains, la creation de plaoes dans les centres populeox, le rem- placemeut progressif des anoiennes hanitations homides par d'autres plus bygi^niques.

Non seulement les Alexaudrins ne demandent pas les pares de la Roe Rosette pour servir de poumons k la ville dans uo quartier oil il n'y en a pas besoin, mais enoore ils protestent ^nergiquemeut contre l'intention de la Municipality de priver ainsi les habitants du meilleur emplacement pour cons:ruire dei maisons k bon marohy, k proximity du centre. Sauls les propriytaires fonciers qui sont in- tyressys k maintenir Taugmentation des loyers et qdi ne peuvent pour le moment s'emparer de oette vaste yteudoe de terrains trouvent leur intdrdt k ce qu'ils soient provisoirement transform^ en paros. Pour la masse des con- tribuables il serait mille tois preferable qu'ils fassent imm^diatemeut vendos comma terrains k batir pour enrayer la hausse auormale des loyers.

Voilk oe qu'il fallait dire pour ydairer le Minister sor les vyritables dy*irs de la popn- lat'on de notre ville. Ei r^istant paraellement aux exigences de la Municipality, il nous a rendu un vt-ritable service. 11 faut dono espyrer qo'il s'affermira dans cette eonduite.

div.head: LE DRAME DE L'ATTARIN.
div.p: 1ES RESPONSABIL1TES

On a dyjk beaucoop ypiloguy sur le drame de 1'AttariD, dont a yty viotime le Dr. Varve- roponlo. Mais o'est en gynyral ponr faire de la psychologie et s'attendrir sur la famille du mydeoin et sur le meurtrier lui-mGme, sans s'attacher k dyconvrir les responsabilitys.

Elies existent, cependant. La Municipality taille dans son budget un gateau de trois mille livres pour treize mydecins qui sont k son ser vice. Voilk qui est bien, puisque le drame rd- ceut dymontre la nycessity pour la ville d'avoir continuellement k sa disposition un personnel rytribuy par les contribuables. Mais lk on commence la responsability de l'administration, o'eat dans l'ignorance cu elle laisse la population de ce service public, payy de pes denier?. Personne k Alexandrie ne connalt l'existence des mydecins munioipanx, et ce qui le prouve, e'est que la presse n'en a pas sootHy mot dans ses commentaires.

Si la Municipality, comme c'ytait son devoir, avaiten Boin de faire afiioher de temps h autre- que les malades en qu6te d'an mydeoiD pendant la unit pouvaient s'adresser anx dooteurs payys par la ville, le jeone Perrini n'anrait pas eu besoin d'aller frapper k sept k huit portes et le msnrtre du Dr. Varveropoulo etit yty yvity.

L'Administration a mGme ponssy si loin l'in- ourie sur ce point qu'ell9 n'a pas fait insorire les noms des docteurs en question dans le bureau de la Sociyty des Secours d'Urgence on les parents des malades courent d'abord, comme e'est arrivy ponr M. Perrini.

A quoi Bert dono de rytribuer un personnel mydioal pour les besoins de la ville, si on ne fait pas connaltre l'existence de ce personnel anx interests T En agidsant de la sor'e, la Municipality se rend ooupable non seulement de nygligence, mais encore de gaspillage; et quand un crime en rd julte, elle en endosse la responsability.

div.head: EMANCIPATOIN OF EGYPT
div.p: Some mouths ago we reviewed a work entitled the "Emancipation of Egypt.'' This book is still attracting attention and a Cairo correspondent of the "Phare d'Alexsndrie ' makes the followiug reflections as to its authorship : —

L'autei r anonymo qui publie ses deux cent cinquante pages, en trois laugues, chez trois grauds yditeurs dei capitales occidentals de l'Earope, dans les nations qai ont les plus grands inUrets en Egypte, neurit pas pour les stadioux. Il est done yvideut que nous nous trouvons en prysonce d'un livre ycrit "sar commande "et dans on but politique.

Il s'agit, maiutenant, de retrouver quel peut 6tre ce but. Le bat apparent est contenu dans le titre: l'Emancipation de l'Egypte. Dans le corps de I'ouvrage l'iddo se pryciae davantage et devient la naotralisation de l Egypte. Or ce q i frappe k la lecture de ce livre, e'est qae tandis qae l'autear y dymontre n oe connaissance complete de la vie ygyptienne, en tout ce qui concerne les dytails, quand il s'agit du vif de la question, k savoir la capacity de l'Egypte k former ua corps national indtSpeiylaut, le m6nn auteur exbibe uue ignorance qui ue peat etre qu'iuteutionuelle. Le livrp, on le voit k ce detail, est fait pour les publics europyen0, iguorauts deja questior, qae U devise s^duisaute du veil d'anc nation pent aisyment tromper. Mais comme l'auteur n'est pas dupe, lui-meme, de ce qu'il dit, il s'ensuit que le but apparent du livre, n'est pas celui qui est iuscrit sar la couver- tare, laqaelle n'est qu'uu drapoau qui couvre uue marchaudise da contrebaude. Il ne nous est pas diflidle de rattacher cette tentative an monvemeat panislamique (ini donne, depuis que'que temps, des signed d'activity trks manifested

D'aprbs que'ques dytails que j'ai pu me procmer, e'est la Sociyty paniblamique de Londres, laquolle vieut de fouder une li iale k Paris, qui est k la tS:e de oe moQvement Cette sociyty ytant sovtoot et poor le moment, une sociyty scientifique, il ne paralt pas yirange qu'elle ait chargy qjelqae auoien foaotionnaire europyen retrain du gouvema- meut ygyptien d'yerire oet ouvrage, destiny k poser devant l'opiuiou europyenue la question de l'ymauoipatiou da l'Egypte, au momeut mfime oil devant l'Europe offioieile se place la qoeitiou d'accorder k l'Augleterre uue plus graude liberty d'actiou dans la valiya da Nil. L'importance qua 1'Egypte pour l'lslam u'est pas mince. L'Egypte est la rygion, oil les Musulmans ont atteint an degry de civilisation plus yie7y et de liberty plus grande : le Cairo est la principal9 ville islam:que : A1 Azhar est le foyer de la pensye musulmaue. D'Algyrie anx Indes, l'Egypte est la piste sur laqaelle tonmo le m >nda masalman. L'E'ypte, devenue, si c' ytait possible, an Etat masnlman organ'que et libra de/rait faire rayounar son intiuence sur tons les penp'es da la mGme religion. La race blanche a trouvy son compytiteur en Ext Sine Orient: la oh'Stientd le troaverait sur les bords memos de la MSditerranSe. C'est le but incmna de riuconuu Scrivain de 1' ymanoipatiou de l' Egypt.

div.head: LA PROMENADE FATALE
div.p: Un confry.-e du Cairo remarq 10 : — Depuis quelque tamps, k l'baare snob de la promenade, uu ocuple d'yiygantes danns torques, paryas telles des obAises, adressaient, de lear viotoria k deux chevaux, leurs plus enga- geants sourires aox jeuces efleudis de leur conuaissance.

Eucouragyes peutfitre par le succks de jour eu jour croissant de leurs affaires—ces damee habitant Clot Bay—elles eureot mfime l'inoon- oavable audace d'attirer, par one mimique das pins prometteases, l'atteutiou d'uu des plus bants foDCtionuaires da Cairo.

Mai lear en prit. Cet homme haot place y*Ait par basard vertueux et son indignation fut sans homes. E'.le se tradnisit par nne plainte adrassye k la police et elle eut poor eflet 1'arrestation et la condamnation des belles pficheresses k one amende de P.T. 100.
Il ne fnt pa3 juflqu'k Yarbagui trOuant ear le siege de U victoria qui ne re9fit, outre une forte ryprimande, nue punition exemplaire pour sa tacite complicity.

Lea gens vertueux—qui sont en majority an Cairo—ne ponrront qu'applandir k la mesnre prise en oette oirconstanoe et rendre hommage :i la pndeor du fonctionnaire haut placy qoi s'est (5ma devant an geste... que la morale qualifie d'obsckne.

div.head: AVIS
div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudication les travaux de prolongement de la rue des Parcs au sud de l'ancien cimetière israélite jusqu'au fort el Nahas.
Le cautionnement est fixé à LE. 120.
Le cahier des charges est déposé an Bureau de la Voirie où il peut-être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 18 courant.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation la même jour à 5h.p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: "Soumission pour les travaux de prolongement de la rue des Parcs."

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une banque, d'après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 18 courant à midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée.
L'Administrateur.
(signé) W.P. Chataway.
Alexandrie, le 21 Aoft 1906.

div.head: HUNGARY'S PLAGUE OF LOCUSTS.
div.p: Scientists are now very busy in Hungary attempting to explain the reason for the unprecedented visitation of an army of locusts. The damage done by the loonsts iB at the moment impossible to be ganged. No one nnacqoainted with the devastating possibilities of these winged pests woald for a moment imagine that they, and they alone, were responsible for so much wholesale destruction.

One could not believe one's own eyes. Everything they swooped upon perished as at the hand of a ruthless invading army. An eyewitness told me of a darkened sky, as if the night had suddenly enveloped them. The whole thing is in the nature of a calamity. The Pnpzfa, or great Hungarian plain, and in particular Hortobagy, near Debrecen, is now in a state of cattle fodder famine.

Specialists suggest that the locusts came from Morocco, but it is the huge number which has baffled their scientific skill, they are computed to be at thousands of billions. Their task of destroying 18,000 square kilometres of highly productive land was most successfully accomplished. Barley, wheat, rye, maize, and also beetroot and turnips, all come within their scheme of destruction, and in some cases they ate away even to the roots.

The damage, though only dimly understood at present, is considered to be enormous. Unfortunately, the loousts are likely to remain in the conntry for another fortnight, as they have j ust laid their eggs. The direction now taken by them is towards Balmaz"j 'kros and ilajdubuszormdny.

div.head: CAPE CAIRO RAILWAY DEVELOPMENT.
div.p: The munificent bequest of the late Mr- Alfred Beit for the furtherance of Mr. Rhodes's great scheme for a railway to cross Africa from sooth to north has brought the aoco!h plishment of the scheme very appreciably nearer. At the present time the line stretches from Capetown to nearly 300 miles north of the great Victoria Falls, and is rapidly approaching the boundary of the Congo Free State through which it will probably pass on its way northwards though this is not yet definitely settled, and there is an alternative scheme for the line to follow the trans African telegraph wire through German East Afrioa. Roughly speaking, and taking Capetown BB the starting-point of the line, 2,f00 miles of railway have now been completed, and as a result of Mr. Beit's brquest (the "Morning Post" states) the rate of progress in construo tion will be greatly stimulated. Hitherto the line has been built in separate sections, following the policy laid down by Mr. Rhodes several years ago. These sections are about 1,000 miles in length, and each ope is taken in hand by itself, the capital is raised for it, and the construction carried forward with a view to enabling it to pay its own way, without reference to the rest of the line, at the earliest possible moment. With the million sterling that Mr, Beit has left at their command those in charge of the constrnotion will no longer find their hands tied and their work impeded through lack of funds, so that a very great difficulty will have been removed from their path.

Years ago, when he was first sketching out his plans for the line, Mr. Rhodes foresaw trouble in raising the capital necessary for the construction and maintenance of the portions of the railway tjiat passed through the interior "In Rhodesia and for some d'sffanpe nor!h ot the Zambesi," he said in effect, "there is something tangible to offer to investors. There are the goldfields of Rhodesia and there are the Wankie ooaifield at the Victoria Falls and the rich and extensive copper deposits in Northern Rhodesia. But once you are beyond these regions and have plunged into the almost unknown interior, wbat have you to offer a man in older to induce him to put his money into ihe scheme ?" This trouble has now, to a very large extent, at all events, been removed, and appropriately enough, by Mr. Rhodes' old friend and partner. It is very probable that the whole cf the money left to the railway by Mr. Beit will be devoted to buildiDg the line through thr se regions which offer no immediate prospect of paying their way, and that the Chartered Company will continue to guarantee the capital necessary for the sections where good returns are to be looked for under similar terms to those portions that have already been laid and opened for traffic. The Beit bequest makes it absolutely certain tljat the line will be completed in its entirety and that,moreover, within a comparatively sh'ort time. It has come just at the right moment, and will enable the work to be poshed forward with undiminished energy.

At present the rai'head is in the neighborhood of the Broken Hill district, with its valuable copper and z'nc mines, and the survey for the next section is being vigorously pushed forward by Sir Charles Metcalfe, the engineer of the line, and those working with him. The route which it is proposed that this section shall take is from Broken Hill to tfie curious little settlement of Bwone Macubwa, dose to the boundary line which divides North-West Rhodesia from the Congo Free State. This settlement is said to stand amid copper deposits of almost fabnlons extent and valne, while there are also numerous caves of beautiful greeu malachite. These are of surpassing loveliness, and have, of course, very considerable commercial importance. At the present time there are only two or three adventurous whites here, but when once the line is open to the sonth there is every probability of a great mining rnsh taking place as soon as the resources of »he district become generally realized. For the present all the effort to the construction staff will be concentrated upon reaching Bwme Maoubwi as quickly as possible, The usual rate of progress is about one miles a day, though as much as 5 J miles of track have bseu laid in a single working day of 12 hours. This achievement, by the way, is believed to be a world's record,

There are very few engineering dilfioultiea to be dealt wi*h over this portion of the route. The country through which the line will run is for the most part a high tableland, with an average altitude of about 4,590 feet above sea leve1, and broken up wi*h small valleys. The district is p'entifally supplied with water for its whole extent, and the climate is said to be ideal for E iropouiP. A bridge some 1,500 feet in length is necessary to carry the line across the Kafne River, but after this the country, frun an engiueer's point of view, is very eaRy. When this distriot is opened op by means of the railway line it is likely to have a very considerable effort upon the whole of Africa, in as much as it has a large native population that is very willing to work either on the line or, it is thought, in the mines of Rhodesia and the Rand.

While many people are content to jndge the tran8-Af>ic8n line solely on its commercial possibilities, Mr. Beit was one of those who regarded it quite as much for its importance ss a civilising influence, and certainly fin advent of the line 1 as -completely altered the sitnatior, and altered it for the better, in mary of the regions through which it has pasped. For one thing, the iniquitoos slave trade ot the interior, so rampant only a few years ago, is now almost entirely stamped ont.

So far as the line has gone it has thoroughly justified all the most optimistic hopes of its founder. There were many to be feund both athome and in Sonth Africa who denonnoed the extension of the line northwards from Bula wayo to the Viotoria Falls as the mad dream of a visionary and one which could not possibly be jastifivi on commeroial grounds. The resolt, however, has completely disproved these allegations. Already the Wankie coalfield ranks among the most important of its kind in Sonth Africa and the traffic from here is increasing every month. The extension of the line into Northern Rhodeua, too, has led to the rapid development of copper mining in this territory and precisely similar results are to be looked for in the cate of the Broken Hill- Bwone Maoubwa 9eotion as soon as it is open for traffic.

At the other end of Africa the Egyptian Government at the moment is discussing the advisability of constructing another great dam across the Nile at Rosaires, and should this be done the railway is certain to be extended from Khartoum to the new works with a possible extension as far as the Viotoria Nyarjia in order to form a junction with the Uganda II lilway. When it is added that the distance, measured in a straight line from the Viotoria Nyacza to Lake Tanganyika, is only six hundred miles, the significance of this extension when considered in connection with the Cape- to Cairo scheme as a whole is plainly to he recognized.

It is not too much to say not only that Mr. Beit's gift to the line has made it oertain that it will, as has already been said, now be oarried through in its entirety, bat it oan also be deolared that it has brought the date of its completion forward by at least five years. No time is likely to be lost in taking full advantage of the money which has so unexpectedly become available, and the whole scheme now takes new life at the moment when, if it was not exaotly languishing, it was at all events becoming a question whether it wonld be wise to carry the line much farther than the houndary of fhe CoDgo Free State. The only ipatter for regret is that neither of the two paen to whoip the line is phiefiy due has lived long enough to witness its consummation,

div.head:
THE MACEDONIAN METROPOLIS
HABITS AND CHARACTERISTICS OF THE PEOPLE.
div.p: Tourists do not go to Macedonia ^because of the difficulties and danger, but if they did (says Mr. F. Moore, writing in the current number of the "Sunday at Home") they would find a show that no other part of Europe can produce. Not only is the roomie opera stage out-done in variety and novelty of costumes, in characters and in complexity of plot, but the scenery set in Alpine mountains on a vaster scale than Switzerland can afford ; and besides, the stage is decked with relics of the ages which would interest men who have travelled far.

Salonioa is said to be richer than ary city of Greece in ecclesiastical remains, and itsanpient stracture8, for the most part, have borne well the ravages of time. There are many great edifices built by the Romans daring their occupation $nd by the Greeks in their tippe stilh'n use—a minaret at tfie corner of eaoh denotes the purpose tfiese one-time churches serve to-day. There is a morque of St. Sophia at Salouica, built, like its great sister at Constantinople, daring the reign of Justinian, and with a history replete with bickerings between Orthodox aDd Catholic churcfies—until the Turks made a mosque of it. Mosques are the most numerous places of worship in Salonics, bat many mosques go to few Turks. In proportion as the mosques ontnumber the synagogue0, the Jews outnumber the Turks. Tfiese Jews, like many of those in Constantinople, a e, strangely eoougfi, of Spanish origin, fugitives who fled the fn- qaisition in the days of Ferdinand and Isabella. While they are the most numerous people of this seaport town, they form in Macedonia one of the lesser of fhe several races that exist and maintain their individuality under the Turk. Like the Christian people, they live apart, still speak their own language in their homes, dress in their own way, follow their own habits, and keep distinctly to themselves,

"Many ot the men cf Maoedonia wear a form of skirt. If one arrives at Salonica iu the afternoon of a Jewish Sabbath his first impression is invariably that he has landed among a raoe of bearded women. The quay is thronged with promenading Jews in dressing gowns made of the most wonderful designs in cotton prints. These gay figured garbs of many colours hang straight from the shoulders to the heels, broktm only by a red sash, yards in length, wound round and round the man till it forms a thick wad. Into this, money, oigarette-boxes, beads, and other odds and ends are stuffed, and in the oase of Turks, pistols and knives ; for this sash, which takes the plaoe of pockets, is the one article of olothing which all the natives have in commoD. The costume of the married women is most extraordinary an i unbecoming. A green cap within a border of red, and a chin-strap of still another colour, fits over the head and falls in a narrow bag behind to their waists. Into this bag the hair is stuffed, for the same reason that in Russia some seots of Israelites shave their heads. In ehirts the women also go in for gaudy prints, and, like the men, wear, over a'l, fur lined greatcoats.

div.head: THOUGH REGISTERED ABROAD MUST PAY.
div.p: FAR-REACHING DECISION-

The question whether a company registered abroad, but doing business from London, is liable to pay income tax in London on the whole of its profits wherever made paid to its shareholders, was raised yesterday week in the House of Lords before the Lord Chancellor in the case of De Beers Consolidated, Ltd., v. Howe (Surveyor of Taxes).
As the question is one that effects a large number of companies, the decision of their Lordships is one that has been watched for with some anxiety in City circles.

The Commissioners found that the trade or business of the appellants constituted one trade or business, and was carried on at their London office, whence the chief operations of the Company, both in the United Kingdom and elsewhere, were managed, controlled, and directed, and tidy accordingly held the whole of the profits liable to income tax.
The Court of Appeal affirmed that decision, and the Company appealed to their Lordships.

The Lord Chancellor, in moving that the appeal should be dismissed, said that under the schedule to the Income Tax Act, 1853, any person residing in the United Kingdom must pay on his annual profits or gains arising or acoruing to him "irom any kind of property whatever, wfiether sitnate in the United Kingdom or elsewhere," and also from any profession, trade, employment, or vocation, whether the same shall be respeotively carried on in the United Kingdom or elsewhere. Ticino once generation,

Mr. Cohen, far the appellants, maintained that a company resided where it was registered, and nowhere else. If that were so, the appellants must succeed, for admittedly it was only registered in South Africa.

But his Lordship could no$ adopt Mr. Cohen's contention, lor in applying the conception of residence to a company he thought they ought to proceed as nearly as they could upon the analogy of ag individual. An individual flight be of foreign nationality and yet reside in the United Kingdom. So might a company. Otherwise it misfit have its chief seat of management and its seat of trading in England under the protection of English law and yet escape appropriate taxation by the simple expedient of being registered abroad, and distributing its dividends abroad,
It was laid down more than thirty years ago that a company resided for the purposes of its income tax where its real business was carried on. The Commissioners had found that that placa was London.

it followed that this company was resident within the United Kingdom for the purposes of income-tax, and most be assessed on that footing. He desired to add that he agreed with the Master of the Rolls that the residence of a company within the meaning of the Income Tax Acts was not necessarily the same thing as residencies for the purpose of serving a writ.
Their Lordships agreed in this decision, and the appeal was accordingly dismissed with costs.

div.head: LANCASHIRE COTTON BOOM ENDS.
div.p: In his latest statement as to cotton-spinning mill building in Lancashire, Mr. William Tattersall says the boom is over, and at the present time no projects for erecting factories are reported. Weaving shed extensions, he states, are going on, but here also new places are coming to an end. The 009t to machinery and the equipping of a spinning mill is much higher than a year or so ago, the estimated increase being, in a mill of 120,000 spindle, about ££0,000. The heavier cost for yarn skips is a serious matter. It is interesting to note that the automatic horn is making progress in various districts.

div.p: Connections made with the most important trains of the State Railway in the Provinces of Behera, Gharbieh, Dakahlieh Charkieh and Galioubieh.Through service for goods between all stations of the Company andover 100 principal stations of the State Railway in Upper and Lower Egypt. Goods may also be through-booked from or to any station on Helouan Railway. The Company has 70 stations opened for public Telegraph Service in conjunction with all offices of the Government Telegraph Department.For time tables, tariffs and information apply to the offices at Cairo, Alexandria Damanhour, Tantah or Zagazig. 21416 31-12.905

Alexandria, Port-Said, Suez, Luxor, Assuan, Haifa, & Khartum.
GENERAL RAILWAY AND STEAMSHIP AGENTS. BANKERS.
BAGGAGE AND FORWARDING AGENTS.
Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.

RESIDENTS IN EGYPT proceeding to Europe for the summer are requested to apply to our offices for information respecting their Passages, where steamer plans may be consulted and Berths secured by all Lines of Steamers to all parts of the Globe; arrangements can also be made for the collection and forwarding of their baggage and clearance at port of arrival.

CIRCULAR NOTES issued payable at the current rate of exchange in all the principal cities of Europe. Cook's Interpreters in uniform are present at the principal Railway stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their travelling tickets.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Wady-Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum. Moderate fares.
FREIGHT SERVICE, Steamers leave Cairo every Saturday and Tuesday for Assouan and Halfa.
Special Steamers and Dahabeahs for private parties.
Special arrangements for tour in PALESTINE, SYRIA and the DESERT, Lowest Rates.
